review_title: Amazing Mission and Place to Work
pros: DEI is prioritized. Coworkers and most of the management team are phenomenal to work with. I greatly enjoy my work and the mission. The benefits and salary can be competitive IF you work hard and constantly upskill. Standard benefits are more competitive than most corporate companies especially in the non-profit industry. Overall a great place to work!
cons: They are growing too fast to sustain the mission, always trying to do more with less. The administration doesn't seem to take into full consideration the level of burnout in the departments they oversee. Why do I think this (or assume this)? Job backfills are constantly on hold; budgets are cut; learning and development take a back seat even though managers'/supervisors' hearts are in the right place. People are constantly resigning, leaving those that have to pick up the slack to burnout. This is all too common in most workplaces though and cannot fault COH given the current economy, post-pandemic era etc. Remote work  life should be embraced however since the world has changed and should not require those exclusively working from home to come back.

review_title: Departing has vastly improved my mental well-being
pros: Good pay for nonprofit, wide range of benefits. Patient care is great.
cons:
Where to begin... first off, I am not a disgruntled employee. I was promoted more than once but left due to the terrible culture.

Leadership suffers from a severe inability to prioritize and align the organization around strategic initiatives. Success is rewarded with doubt, questioning and a weird mix of higher accountability in some settings and complete indifference in others. Meanwhile mediocrity and disengagement are widely accepted and longtime employees who contribute little in the way of modern/marketable skills are revered. Toxic dysfunction and bullying are common despite the institution’s professed values. Employees raising legitimate concerns are gaslighted and often pegged as the problem.

I’m an experienced professional in my field and I have never experienced the kind of malignant challenging of my expertise by people with absolutely no experience in my field as I did at City of Hope. You must be willing to sacrifice your belief in yourself and your abilities in favor of belief in the institution (no matter how misguided) in order to be successful. 

All of this leads to an environment where turnover is quite high, many people leave very soon after being hired, and many are actively hunting while their skills deteriorate due to the outdated thinking, tools and processes they work within at COH.

It took some distance from COH, and time in a modern/positive work environment, for me to be able to articulate all of this. Many seem quite happy there, but I would never consider returning.

review_title: Joined because of the impactful mission, but the company's management and politics have gotten so bad as to overpower it
pros: Important mission with an impressive history, beautiful campus, good medical benefits

Employees regularly work there for 6-8 years without being promoted, and when they are, it is often due to seniority not performance - thus, little incentive to go that extra mile. Upper management is incompetent and has gotten away from the mission. HR is useless and only looking out for the company - they do not care about the employees. Recently there have been some external hires who have brought in an influx of negativity, leaving employees disillusioned and unmotivated. There are internal politics, there is mass disorganization, and the new office in Irwindale is cold, sterile and in the middle of nowhere surrounded by power lines. The fact that there are only 5 legal holidays given per year is a joke. Employees are disgruntled and overworked, for poor compensation. In the past year, the organization has changed dramatically for the worse. Unfortunately, though the mission is admirable, there are countless other equally worth causes and this place is a sinking ship.

review_title: Good experience, with typical large-company problems
pros:
Clinical areas are immaculate, of course. There's free parking for visitors and employees, although most of the parking lots are quite a walk from any of the main buildings. It's very safe even at night, because there's always a security car coming around.

Benefits are good, although it's amusing that if you get cancer, you can't get treated at City of Hope without a referral unless you opt for the most expensive health plan. My immediate supervisor was fantastic, but I've seen some that are very mercurial. Everyone I've met (aside from some of the higher ups) were all very kind.

Unexpected perks included free vaccinations and flu shots, as well as the on-campus mailroom. Too bad they moved it from the middle of campus all the way out to the boonies.
cons:
Although they are getting around to renovating all the labs, there's a definite drop in quality compared to the hospital proper. Because of the constant renovations, there's always construction going on and you sometimes have to direct lost patients/visitors. At least they send out emails about road closures.

There's also a ton of red tape. Buildings can be slated for renovation/demolition for years while they wait for a signature.

If you work in academic research, your pay will just be barely enough to live on, but that's a given wherever you are. I've seen a lot of politics play out as well.

Unfortunately, they are downsizing staff because they're expecting to lose some major lucrative patents in the next few years. Seeing some of the lavish fundraisers they put on while knowing that so many scientists have been very suddenly laid off is sometimes disheartening.

review_title: The Worst Career Move You’ll Ever Make
pros: It was close to home.
cons:
They’ll woo you with tales of lives saved and the wonderful contributions you’ll make to help cure illness.  At staff meetings they’ll bring in patients and doctors who will tell stories of miraculous recoveries and promising discoveries.  There won’t be a dry eye in the room.  But it’s all a con.

The truth is, the culture is toxic.  They have a group of abusive managers who have been there a long time and are untouchable.  These managers create drama and chaos, making the organization ineffective.  Anyone who tries to improve the situation is treated as a threat.    

Another distressing situation is the waste of donations.  They do whatever it takes to get money from donors, but much of the money is wasted on very expensive consultants and flawed software.   

In 2018, COH's patent revenue ends.  It's a significant income stream and they do not have anything in process to replace the money.  Expect the drama and dysfunction to increase the money dries up and each department is required to cut expenses and do more with less.  

If you manage to avoid the bad managers and the drama, you’ll still have to deal with a sclerotic, antagonistic and overbearing bureaucracy.

review_title: Just a matter of time..Please hire staff who are able to understand the data, if you want it reported correctly.
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Duarte, CA

It's once iconic image may be damaged beyond repair with sponsors and the community at large.  A recent shake-up has led to some drastic measures by executive management to regain control and salvage the reputation.
cons: Too many layers of middle management within the CTO has led to disastrous consequences in the Clinical Trials Office, a site with over 100 active clinical trials. Advances in immunology and genetics have led to targeted therapies with small molecules and monoclonal antibodies whose sponsors demand advanced training for research coordinators. Who is so complacent to assume that all these changes in medicine, would not require changes in the workforce? The workforce of the 1980s, in the age of CAR-T. Don't think so, The old guard of the  CTO, lead by fear and insecurity, lest they are found out.  Research staff left to their own devices will compensate for deficiencies with disastrous results.

pros:
City of Hope creates miracles,  has a gorgeous campus,  and committed employees. 

They organization offers a Learning and Personal Development week each year where speakers and trainers are brought in to lead dozens of short sessions on a variety of topics. 

Unfortunately,  that is the extent of professional development offered to most staff.
cons:
From the perspective of the business and IT functions,  City of Hope is disorganized and unfortunately plagued with employees who have not received the training and development to remain relevant and effective.  This seems to be the case from the staff level up to the senior management levels. 

HR seems to pride itself in declining raises and promotions, resulting in the best and brightest abandoning the firm. 

In spite of a comprehensive strategic plan, and magnificent researchers and doctors,  the company seems to be on a down hill slide. It's bound to impact the level of care patients receive and the company's ability to remain competitive.

pros: The pay here is fantastic and the job is rewarding.  Even in IS it's great to know that we're helping positively impact patients with cancer.  Occasionally get to tackle challenging projects.  The hospital campus is beautiful.  Patient facing values are great.
cons: IS is very middle management heavy and nepotism is rampant.  People who seem to barely know their job are promoted very quickly (multiple times in a couple years).  Teams have "workhorses" who they rely on too heavily.  Communication is terrible, whether it's cross team or from executive level down.  Multiple reorgs in just a few years leading to a constant feeling of "flux" and lack of stability.  Too many decisions are made in a vacuum with no consideration given to impact.  Little to no career development.  HR is absolutely unresponsive to complaints and there's almost no accountability.  Internal values are poor.

cons:
Lots of red tape: a committee for every tiny detail, even hanging a coat rack needs "approval"

Endless requirements for safety training and ethics

Research staff are not treated like there is any understanding for hours committed to work, for instance working double digit hours per day and on weekends gives no additional compensation, however you are not allowed to "compensate" these hours by taking a day off at any point without declaring "vacation" (which there is not very much of).

I hear the postdoc salaries here are considered very low.

review_title: Great clinical care provider, poor administration
pros: You have the chance to really make a difference in cancer research and the patients' lives. You feel a renewed sense of mission when you walk through the hospitals and see these patients.
cons: Top heavy management loves to hire more directors, senior directors, senior senior directors, senior assistant directors, etc. Management does not care about providing support to their staff. They only care about giving pay raises and promotions to themselves and will make hiring decisions based on their own personal agendas, and not for the good of a department. Management often forgets who's actually doing the work and just gives credit to themselves.

job_title: Medical Assistant/Medical Records Technician in Lancaster, CA
pros: Cant think of a single one.
cons: 'weekends off' isn't true, physicians will schedule clinics on weekends. constantly staying past your scheduled time because clinics are so overbooked and physicians come in late to start clinic, when hired you are given a shift time and that will contently be changing to accommodate physicians and patients, no standard process or expectations across the board so everyone is treated differently and so much disorganization in the clinic. A lot of sloppy work from workers and that completely affects the good workers and the patients, management fully aware but turns a blind eye instead of dealing with issues.

review_title: Myriads of Benefits in Cancer Research
job_title: Senior Applications Analyst in Monrovia, CA
pros: A staff member has the opportunity to work on multiple projects that are pathways to what is called "Bench to Bedside"... Meaning, you work on small to large efforts that lead to cures, or at the least, slowing down cancer and diabetes so that someone gets to live. Additionally, work hours are more than fair and most people from Directors to Admin coordinators seem to always be at least satisfied if not more than passionate about their day to day functions.
cons: Working for a non-profit can have it's downsides as it is just that... a non-profit, not subject to profit sharing, stocks or bonuses. But the 401(k) equivalent is more than fair.

pros: I’ve been at City of Hope for 20 years now and I am proud to say that I work at one of the best cancer centers in the world! City of Hope has excelled in the clinical and research arena. In my tenure at City of Hope, I’ve experienced compassion for their patients and employees. For this, I am very proud and grateful to be part of the City of Hope family.
cons: I don't have any "Cons". I can't express how positive City of Hope has been for me on a professional level, but also in a personal level as I've had family members as patients. City of Hope has been a blessing.

review_title: Good place to work but could improve
pros: Great team of doctors and nurses. High quality care for patients are their top priority. Definitely  exceeds in innovative research to produce state of the art cancer treatments that are producing great outcomes for patients in both quality and quantity of life.
cons:
Not a friendly or cohesive team. Doctors and nurses seem stressed and don't often smile or even say hello in passing. They have grown too fast and can't seem to handle the patients that are arriving. Patients are very ill and have unacceptable waiting times with all appointments. 
Parking is terrible for everyone.

pros:
Last hope for many with terminal diseases
Excellent research facilities (own GMP)
Compensation; although this is changing
Peer to peer environment; although this is changing
cons:
Lack of leadership at the senior level; very little direction but a lot of cheerleading
Waste funds on management studies that go nowhere; wait 6-12 months and do the same thing again
A lot of "feel good" administrative positions and functions at the expense of performing operational positions
Destroying "compassion" atmosphere amoungst employees
Bottom line; a lot of medical research brain power, but way short on organizational and operational skills in leadership.

pros:
One of the best cancer centers in the world! Truly compassionate and dedicated patient care staff.
There are many brilliant scientists doing great work.
cons: On the other hand, Leadership is very disappointing. All recruited, consultant that are hired over dedicated employees. Cant trust leaders, say something against them and eventually you will be eliminated. Mean girl mentality, treacherous and backstabbing. All of leadership is Caucasian. Forget about it if your a minority. Cuts are made at the expense of patient care and good research.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator II in Duarte, CA
pros: As a CRC you are broken up in disease teams. They have family and work life is flexible. Minimal supervision. Great levels of experience. Staff has great personality and supervisors understand the load of work each person has and will stand up for you.
cons: There is a lot of turn over for the entire organization. Difficult to move up in supervisor roles. Frequently have to carry the weight of those leaving so there is no steady pace plus new studies opening up with no change in pay raise or compensation.

review_title: Too good to be true usually is
pros: Competitive salary / benefits, plentiful parking, free coffee / fitness facility, certain employees were passionate and made great business partners.  Superior data management systems and excellent technical teams.
cons: HR did an excellent job of making new hires feel valued and welcomed.  Unfortunately, the dept I worked was not too friendly or professional to new hires starting from day 1.   Management in my dept holds new employees at arms length and does not interact with them at all for about 3 months, which was just weird.

pros:
Nice training opportunities such as courses, seminars. Guest speakers are frequently invited. 
Positive, proud and motivating culture. Great patient care philosophy. The people are very friendly.
cons:
Supervisors and management seem unable to address problems with the individual employee in question. Instead, all staff are accused. 
There is a lack of collegiality, support, respect or trust from supervisor to employee. It's a two class society, the supervisor takes advantage and fails to acknowledge the hard work that the postdocs do. Lab members are often treated like little children.

review_title: Most management is incompetent.  HR is there to protect management, not employees.  Few promote from within,terrible pay
pros: Compensation is limited at 10%, even when changing jobs.  This forces people to leave and come back to get anywhere near industry standard pay.  IT was a well oiled machine with good management, but all of them have been cleared/forced out and replaced by outsiders that have created a toxic work environment.  Stability is laughable.  They have plenty of management, but not enough workers to do the job.  Work life balance is horrible for those with salary/on call positions.  They do try to have company sponsored activities such as BBQ, holiday parties, but hard to attend/enjoy with work schedule.  Basketball and Volleyball court for reecreation, GYM, running track.
cons: Constantly changing bureaucratic mess.  Consistency in management is a joke.  Vacation and holidays are not enough.  Too much time spent working outside of work for no compensation. Highly stressful.  COH hardly promotes from within, instead they use contractors and hire on the ones they like, and fire/layoff long time employees that questions/stand up to management.  This gives little to no room for growth.  Raises hardly cover cost of living.  Parking is a nightmare and they can't even pave some dirt areas that are always parked in.  Vending machines have all been replaced with low calorie options as if I am not smart enough to make my own food choices.

job_title: Senior Research Associate in Duarte, CA
pros: Research community is very supportive and cognizant of each other's research and abilities
cons: Administration is extremely political and decisions are not made based on performance but personal gain to the detriment of good caring individuals

pros: Fantastic compensation, great benefits package, and an even more amazing organization to work for. They truly support you in everything you do, especially during the COVID crisis. City of Hope has greatly supported all of us throughout this pandemic and consistently keeps us updated with on-going communication. They truly care about their employees and I highly recommend COH for anyone considering a career here.
cons: Corporate offices are in the middle of nowhere with very little options for lunch and on-campus options are very pricey.

job_title: Clinical Nurse II Medical Oncology in West Covina, CA
pros: The nursing-patient relationship in this hospital is heart warming and very special. I have learned mostly from my patients who are unfortunately diagnosed with cancer.
cons: 4 patients to 1 nurse in specialty areas with fast turn around.  Leaves the nurse very tired and sometimes can't have anyone to cover for lunch.

review_title: Fantastic team members, not so great leadership, Top-Down Corporate Style Management from some of the higher-ups
pros: Nice campus, mostly good people, admirable mission,
cons: Top-Down Management doesn't promote dynamic leaders much, Performance Reviews are rigged (no employee ever gets the top score, no matter how much they outperform others), Consultants do not engage employees, Consultants are rigid and make decisions that affect employees, Performance Evaluations are inaccurate and demoralizing, somewhat high turnover.

review_title: Great organization, great place to work.
job_title: Campaign Assistant in San Diego, CA
pros: It's a great company to work for with a great vision. Lots of employees are very passionate about the organization and the vision for the future. There is a lot of community support in San Diego for City of Hope which makes fundraising easier than at organizations with less support. San Diego's events are very classy and very well run with great board members.
cons: It's a non-profit so it doesn't pay much.

review_title: Good place to work, great cause to work for
pros: I enjoy working at City of Hope because I know that I'm making a difference in the lives of patients and families here and around the world.  I will never make the money that I might in the for-profit world, but I knowing that I'm part of changing the way cancer is treated makes it worthwhile.
cons: First off, the location isn't the greatest. Secondly, as in all large organizations, the troops sometimes hear rumors and half-truths, before officially being informed.

review_title: Compassionate Experts for Patients, Families & Colleagues
job_title: Executive Director, Non-Profit in Duarte, CA
pros: Physicians, nurses, mental health and other supportive care professionals all profoundly committed to providing the best comprehensive biopsychosocial care in the world. The COVID-19 pandemic demonstrated the mutual respect and unwavering support leadership and colleagues have for each other. The compassion, courage and Grace Under Fire of the staff brought out the best in each other. It is an honor to be part of the team!
cons: High expectations for teamwork, commitment, compassion and honesty that may not be a good fit for some.

pros:
- Depending on where you work it can be a great experience.  The mission is great and there are many people who really care about their work and what they do.  Even when you are not in direct patient care, there are opportunities that make you feel like you are making a difference.
- The campus is beautiful and some of the newer buildings are really nice to work in.
- Fairly flexible schedule in most of the departments I have worked in.
cons:
- Politics and poor management.  While there are some departments where there are good managers, there are many which don't.  I have personally experienced management with very preferential hiring and treatment of employees that are not based on skill (race and gender usually).

- Preferential treatment by executives for their favorite employees and projects instead of what is good for the company and the mission.  This causes a great deal of politician strife between groups, discouraging collaboration and cooperation.

- The last few years there have been lay-offs across much of the company, so stability is questionable. There are always very limited resources with many specific jobs, where they will have only one person performing specific tasks, only they know how to perform. When they leave or are laid off there are huge gaps in knowledge and detrimental effects on the employees around them, and no one seems willing to fix this issue.  Employees usually need to work long hours to make up for the lack of enough people available to do the job in the time required.

- Lack of training opportunities.  It is difficult to get training due to lack of budget and willingness to invest in employees.  There have been multiple cases where my colleagues have had to pay for training themselves.

job_title: Research Associate II in Duarte, CA
pros: Great place for your first job in the research field. Ample opportunity to learn new techniques and gain lots of hands on experience
cons: Promotions are a joke along with the pay in general. HR and management are constantly trying to prevent promotions for individuals who deserve it. Benefits are ok but nothing spectacular. There is a great chance that you will be overworked and underpaid (depending on the department and the lab you work for of course). Too many politics all around but you do see that pretty much everywhere you go.

pros: An amazing history and fabulous philosophy and mission. Beautiful campus setting. Many dedicated professionals who are committed to providing quality care - yet morale is low and people feel concerned about their future as they see great people let go.
cons: Despite many wonderful qualities, there are many challenging aspects to working at City of Hope. Unfortunately, there is a willingness to exploit staff, too many politics and too often a toxic work environment that contributes to low staff morale and dissatisfaction.

review_title: Terrible place to work, public has no idea what is really going on.
job_title: Assistant Research Professor, Virology in Duarte, CA
pros: Well manicured campus grounds.  Hospital Administers do a 1st rate job of weeding out cancer sufferers who don't have top rate health insurance.
cons: Lab heads and departmental managers are enriching themselves from donations and at the expense of tax payers.  Old, washed up professors making multi-6 figure salaries and doing 'experimentation' on antiquated, disproven theories to justify their inflated paychecks.  Not uncommon for scientists/ professors to fire long serving lab staff who are honest and hardworking just to protect their own skin when it is discovered they are pushing fraudulent ideas or two-timing the institute by running side businesses that breach corporate compliance.

review_title: Mgmt s is top heavy- lots Sr VPs, VPs, Managers.  Leaders hire buddies fr revious companies
pros: Medical benefits are great; 80 hrs of sick day; some telecommute work may be allowed.
cons: Nepotism in the workplace.Company does not recognize how much work/projects given to our dept but do not want to hire additional staff.   Very disorganized   The only company I've worked where there were so many people fired because of leadership's mistake.

review_title: start doing what's best for patient and staff.
pros: Wonderful Coworkers.  Lots of teamwork.  Patient always first.  Very compassionate hardworking highly skilled staff
cons: Adminstration top heavy.  Too many chiefs not enough indians.  Lots of politics.

review_title: A leader in Cancer research with a focused mission and vision.
pros: Reasonable pay, benefits, and growth opportunities. Compassionate providers and patient-centric environment. Organization going through transformation to improve the patient experience. People who work here like their job.
cons: Underhanded and unethical leadership in patient access. Huge politics. There are constant changes in management which provides no stability to employees. Lead by fear, which fosters a hostile work environment.

job_title: Senior Systems Analyst in Duarte, CA
pros: Great people, great contributions to cancer community.
cons: Difficult to grow, managers have very little experience managing, typical health care company silos, my division saw three different Vice Presidents in 3 years. Most of the employees are in fear of being laid off even though the average employee has been there 10 years that they do very little socializing and fun employee events.

pros: Many world class doctors and scientists dedicated to saving lives. Decent benefits for a nonprofit.
cons:
Used to be a wonderful place to work, but today it is a demoralizing, soulless and dysfunctional organization.

The “new” COH is all about the things that no employee wants – weak leadership, no vision, fear based management, rampant politics, no growth opportunities, inflated executive salaries and egos. This tyrannical management style, bureaucracy, and fake “engagement” is supported and encouraged by leadership. HR has a crazy amount of power, but not for the good of employees.

Some of the senior executives hired in the last year are the antithesis of any of the spouted cultural “values”. There is bullying and a very negative culture that's been created.  Talented staff is either pushed out or running out the door. Some people were even let go while on medical leave – from this fine medical institution.

The outrageous expenses allowed at the top are totally incongruous with the message pushed down to the ranks. All we hear about is cost cutting and savings, but millions upon millions have been spent on huge new hire salaries (e.g. bringing in execs at $300K, $500K and more! Plus relocation fees, bonuses, etc.). Millions upon millions spent on consultants. 

Leadership can’t trust its own judgment or make a decision, so they hires consultant after consultant to verify everything. And then are frozen in myriad opinions and ends up doing nothing, or even worse, something useless.

People have reported concerns to HR and senior executives repeatedly, but they don’t do anything about it.  Instead HR spends money on pens and buttons with sappy “inspirational” phrases like “hope starts with us”.  They are now requiring execs to read a book written about “service” by a Cleveland Clinic executive. How pathetic to spend money on a mandatory book written by the competition. 

Though it’s a cancer institute that tosses around catchphrases like “compassionate care” there is no compassion for employees and most certainly no care.

review_title: Nice city and people are so nice and kind.
pros:
Work place is nice, people in my department are kind and happy to help you. 
It doesn't have a stressful work life. 
Lot of social activities.
cons: Personally, I don't like work in a hospital. You saw those cancer patients are suffering. My work only related to data analysis. Even though, when I saw the statistics from the data, it makes me depressed.

review_title: Focus more on your core strength that is Research!
pros:
Suburb LA & close to home.
Excellent mission & research group and a beautiful campus.
Open to new Ideas in general.
cons:
Trying to sustain in the Healthcare changes with most of the drug royalties are void in 2018.
Multiple campus, employees spend a lot of time shuttling between admin & main campus.
Directionless IT leadership with no strategies.

review_title: Anything good is long gone and unlikely to be recovered.
pros: Main campus is pretty. The intent of the mission, what little remains, is important and should provide a sense of purpose....to save lives.
cons: Where to begin. Use to be an amazing culture - warm, kind, friendly and collaborative. Even with some flaws people were committed to mission and leadership was sincere and inspiring. Since the new CEO took over it's turned into a dismal, depressing, demoralizing sinking ship. No focus. No vision. No HOPE. Good people leaving in droves due to lack of recognition. HR seems to rule the roost and is completely incompetent starting with its leader and trickling down to the squeaky voiced minions who shake in fear of her. Recently they decided it would be a good idea to lower everyone's title and limit promotions. You never get more than a 2% raise and bonuses are unheard of so don't look for any financial growth opportunity either. That is unless there is a C or V in your title. Check out the 990 and see where all that money is going....those folks are making $300K - $1M a year while everyone else is demorilized for a job well done. New executive hires are some of the rudest, most demeaning and disrespectful folks you'll meet and have totally killed any sense of happiness in some important departments from research labs to clinics to marketing. And none have proven capability or competency to justify the behavior. The CEO speaks like someone reading inspirational posters, but none of his words are sincere. He chose many of the new hires and stands behind them so obviously happy with the destruction of the place. And if all that wasn't enough to cheer you up, they recently moved s bunch of people to a rock quarry in Irwindale where there is no where to walk for lunch or a coffee other than an institutional cafeteria. The closest places are a 15 minute drive each way, thus you're just hostage in a cold, white massive land mine of cubes until the day is over after which you can walk in the dark to a remote parking lot hoping know one will kill you on the way there. Or maybe that would be better than having to show up for a new day of abuse.

pros: Rich history of patient care, enthusiastic supporters and scientific discoveries. Beautiful campus
cons:
Currently lost its way.  Many stops and starts and reversals of decisions. Communication that is stiff and insincere Leaders with values and integrity leaving in droves so "new way" can be implemented.  HR is running the place (until the large staff of lawyers has to step in)
processes take precedent over people. Lack of respect for long term productive employees...unless you are willing to fall into lockstep with the "strategy"

review_title: They don't care about their employees
pros: You get to help patients suffering from cancer
cons: Management doesn't listen, they have favorites and the upper ups only care about money. Its impossible to move up in this company and the union doesn't do anything

review_title: Organization has potential but not aligned
job_title: Human Resources Consultant in Duarte, CA
pros: Strong mission which naturally attracts very talented people who are from all over the world.  A very diverse group of people and skills who come together to do good work.  It's an impression organization that should be thriving but is lacking in leadership.
cons:
Unclear Processes across the businesses and lack of transparency get in the way of this wonderful organization.  

 City of Hope experiences high turnover.  Not a smart company.  Lacks leadership across the company.  Weak ....

pros: The best reason for anyone to work at City of Hope is the collaborative spirit.  Everyone is always willing to lend a helping hand if anyone is seeking assistance and proactively volunteer their efforts to get the job done.
cons: Sometimes the work can be mundane, but that is with any job.  The organization is extremely large and perhaps due to that is very bureaucratic, so there are many many processes in place which definitely hamper timelines.

pros: Great team of nurses to learn from if they are willing to teach. State of the art research center. Outstanding in patient safety. Patient care truly comes first.
cons: Poor union support so same stagnant people hold the nurse teams back. Managers   continue to support strong attitudes instead of hard workers . Many meetings so management is almost nonexistent  to nursing..

pros: They were seemingly willing to provide lots of training and growth opportunities (classes, seminars, and practical experience).
cons: It seemed like the only way to get in was through a temp agency and there was little to no room to actually get promoted.

review_title: Good place to work, though with inconsistent management and culture.
job_title: Assistant Director in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The mission. City of Hope's patient care is some of the best anywhere and the doctors and caregivers really, really care about the patients. Research is fantastic. Culture in parts of the organization are great
cons: Executive management is either not strong or inconsistent across various departments. Culture and morale in the Philanthropy department is especially poor due to weak management.

review_title: The company as a whole does a lot to make employees feel valued and appreciated.
pros: There is an atmosphere of excellence. Company leaders try to engage employees in contributing to workplace improvement.
cons: Very top-heavy. Lots of executive and physician new-hires and layoffs of those in mid and lower level positions. Salary distribution not always equitable. Some departments frown on time off. Opportunities for career growth are limited for some employees.

review_title: Only if you have no other options
pros: Decent benefits and six holidays.
cons:
On a slippery slope. People used to care – about the mission and each other and now it is all about the money….in the paychecks of the executives. 

The CEO has assembled a group of senior executives who are imperious, self-serving and the absolute antithesis of the message put out to the public - that of compassion and caring.  And their salaries are astronomical.  

Lots of titles, but no real leaders.  No speaking truth to power, for sure.  If you’re looking for any guidance or development, forget it.  There is no training, no education, no possibility of growth – not that there’s anyone capable of mentoring.  It’s so top-heavy with upper management whose tangible contributions are non-existent.  And the working staff, whose numbers are thinning quickly as resignations continue to escalate, have seen nothing but title demotions, bonus plans stripped away and 1-2% annual increases.  

The company has unconscionably relocated the non-medical staff to Irwindale, in the middle of nowhere, forcing everyone into a car and a cube.  It’s a dismal, distracting and depressing environment – cold and remote

And face-time is much more important than the actual work. Despite the outlier location, there is no telecommuting policy. If they can’t see you, you must not be working – the general tone is that employees are children who are not to be trusted. 

No one is able to genuinely articulate a vision, or inspire the workforce.  The CEO, and others with titles, can read words written for them when called upon to speak, but there is nothing behind them. Lots of talk from HR about ‘engagement’, which is laughable. It is toxic, demeaning, and punitive.

pros:
Love the mission; what this place does for patients is amazing.  
For the medical staff I hear nothing but good stuff; the business staff seems to be much less satisfied.
cons: Too much of a focus on politics; lots of silos of work that don't communicate; too many areas and projects to focus on makes it tough to get things done.

job_title: Health Information Specialist II in Duarte, CA
pros: Wonderful department to work in.  My co-workers were very friendly and helpful.  I was cross trained in all the jobs in my department.  This helped me to understand how medical records are handled.
cons: No way to move up in the department, but I was happy coming to work every day and doing my job.

job_title: Patient Care Assistant in Duarte, CA
pros: Nice Co-Workers, everyone is encouraging and willing to help if you want to further your education.  Starbucks gives employees discounts and also the cafeteria. Beautiful campus. A great opportunity to start off a nursing career or any other career that you decide in health care
cons: Benefits high for part time employees.  A lot of favoritism between nurses. Lack of leadership, most employees feel entitled as if they can do anything and not get caught.

pros: Top Researchers and Physicians who truly care about their patients.
cons: Low morale that promotes a culture of "bullying" and retaliation from management;  top-heavy management with no regard for administrative staff.

job_title: Clinical LLab Tech in Duarte, CA
pros: Friendly but professional working environment, easy to get along with most personel and develop good relationships with your parents.
cons: Although a nice place to work, there tended to be favoritism and quite a bit of politics by the management when it came to employees that were part of the click. Anonymous complaintaints were pointed out to the one the complaint was filed against many times in gossiping manner

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator II in Duarte, CA
pros: Friendly coworkers, doctors who care, superiors that try to help you, room to grow and learn, flexible hours and ample parking provided.
cons: Regulatory side is slow, heavy work burden, many of their projects are months, sometimes even years, behind and you will be tasked with catching them up.

job_title: Research Associate I in Duarte, CA
pros: It's a great place with a great mission. Everyone I've worked with is very friendly, helpful, and kind. Good work environment, and good emphasis on safety.
cons: The pay could be higher. But I can't really complain since it's an entry-level position. And that's expected in an academic area as opposed to biotechnology.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Duarte, CA
pros: City of Hope has a friendly, collaborative environment and state-of-the-art technology. Research primarily focuses on cancer and diabetes, and we have translational projects through the hospital due to our close ties with the doctors.
cons: As a graduate student, the hours we work nights and weekends are expected despite lack of compensation.

review_title: Life is busy here, and I always work late.
pros: Nice environment. There is a big rose garden in City of Hope, which is very nice. People are professional here.
cons: People are always very busy with different deadlines and of course a lot of pressure. I do not have time for lunch sometimes.

pros: Great mission, offers opportunities for employee development, good work-family balance, various fun events such as employee giving/appreciation, diversity day, BMT reunion etc.
cons: Slacker warning, although soon they will extinct with new leadership. Administration grows fast but not even functional. IT totally fails, no system ever worked properly.

pros: Excellent employer that offers great pay and benefits. Staff are committed and care deeply about the organization's mission. Beautiful campus.
cons: Working day-to-day to fight a difficult disease such as cancer may not be for everyone. Everyone's contribution matters in the battle to defeat cancer, so consider applying only if you know you are passionate and will commit 100% of your effort to the fight.

pros: company provided good benefits to the research side of city of hope.  My direct boss was very generous with her employees.
cons: to much politics with in the company.  it has turned into a corporate instead of trying to heal people and finding cures. HR was the most  horrible  department i had experienced.  Not helpful at all.

job_title: Beloved "moron" With Years of Positive Reviews in Duarte, CA
pros:
Great opportunity to feel you make a difference, regardless of reality.
Excellent people working in down-level management. 
Hiring for now.
If you are a Project Manager with a pulse, come on down!
cons:
Self-Absorbed Chief Officers incompatible with life.
Major Reduction in workforce on horizon in 8 to 12 months.
Greed-fueled Incompetence ignores pernicious corruption amongst vendors. Accenture owns the place. No path to foster and support in-house talent.

review_title: Excellent healthcare organization with great mission, employees, and a reputation that keeps better too!
pros: People love this place.  Lovely campus.  Salary compensation seems to be more competitive than others.
cons: Retirement plan can be better.  Company contributes 6% of salary, but no bonuses or retirement medical plan.

review_title: City of Hope - Lack of opportunity for professional advancement
pros: Good place to work if you desire longevity with a company.
cons: Lack of opportunity for professional advancement.  Management and HR do not support, encourage or promote opportunity for advancement. The culture is non-supportive, whatever position a staff member is hired in the opportunity to promote is almost non-existent especially for minorities.

review_title: Higher salaries make up for other missing perks
pros: People work hard and care about their jobs.  Retirement benefits are terribly meager and there's a 5-year vesting schedule. Fair amount of PTO, and in my position, some work from home flexibility. People tend to be VERY busy. Employees are frequently rewarded with lunches, raffles, etc.
cons: no huge cons for me

review_title: City of Hope is an amazing place to work.
pros:
- Great sense of satisfaction from working for a mission driven organization 
- Excellent team and team work
- Organization supports professional development and frequently promotes from within the organization
cons:
- Organization appears to be going through growing pains as it goes from a more boutique hospital mindset to a national cancer center mindset
- Lacks support for work-from-home days

review_title: Great place to learn, work and advance your career
pros: Excellent people, great location, leading physicians and scientists in their field, and good work ethics
cons: The limitations are Negligible/ None

pros:
Meaningful place to work for. Please do work here if you genuinely want to work with cancer patients. 

Brilliant doctors that care for patients.
cons:
Short staffed at times 
Even though the pay is decent they could do more for employees ; offer more vacation time, health benefits.

review_title: COH could do better for their employees.
pros: Great options for patients who have cancer.
cons: Employees don't feel valued or heard.  The company prefers to hire external candidates rather than give employees who are qualified advancement opportunities.

job_title: Quality Control Associate in Duarte, CA
pros: Inspiring and I feel like I make a contribution to science, good work life balance, good employees, manageable stress level
cons: salary because it's non-profit, wish that managers could show appreciation more by making our opinions count, not much PTO or holidays honored

pros: The scope of work is awesome. The collaborative environment is wonderful. There is no short of learning opportunities.
cons:
Work load depends on the lab. Some labs I have heard are worked hard.
The salaries aren't the best, comparing to biotech industry. The calibration of salaries last year really helped them though.

Benefits are average. 403b is lacking until you reach 5 years, same with PTO accrual.

pros: A very good opportunity to get used to the feel of working an actual job. Very flexible. Many opportunities to learn new things.

review_title: Like most jobs, it depends on your boss(es)...
